docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: David Bookstaber (letter, May 29) argues that pregnant women should be held accountable for their actions because of the ''consequences for a future member of our society.'' Yet studies have shown that drug and alcohol ingestion by the father at the time of conception can also affect the health of the fetus. Will this conduct be actionable?
docs.abstract: Letter from Melanie Rowan-Quinn on David Bookstaber's May 29 letter saying pregnant women should be held accountable for their actions; notes drug and alcohol ingestion by father at time of conception can also affect health of fetus (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The survivors among 800 women used as research subjects 50 years ago in tests that employed radioactive elements would share in $10 million under a tentative settlement, Vanderbilt University said today. Vanderbilt would contribute $9.1 million and the Rockefeller Foundation, which provided money for the original research, would pay $900,000, the university said.

headline.main: National News Briefs; $10 Million Settlement In Radiation Suit

docs.abstract: Vanderbilt University announces that survivors among 800 women used as research subjects 50 years ago in tests that employed radioactive elements will share in $10 million settlement, university to contribute most of money, with Rockefeller Foundation paying $900,000 because it provided funds for original research (S)
